body.div: About 200 black brothers staged a protest rally in front of the home eco­ nomics building Wednesday. Also pre­ sent were about 100 white sympathizers. This rally, unlike past rallies had one important factor. There was a strong sincerity in the sisters and brothers to rid themselves of the problem of discrimination. Often there were black sisters standing with emotion filling their faces, telling it like it is. Brothers were speaking with hard feeling words. They often yelled out at the adminis­ tration telling them to cut out the bull and get to the nitty gritty. University administrator J. Winston standing on the home economics steps looked just like Dennis the Men­ ance's father after finding out his son had done an Injustice to a neighbor. I feel that Martin really wanted to help but like his friend Robert A, Beach, he knew nothing could be done. Beach was called from among the spectators to the witness stand but upon arriving, declined to answer any ques­ tions for fear of incriminating himself. He kept staring at that big administra­ tion building in the foreground of the steps as if he was under some mystical power. The black students constantly asked the two men what were they going to do about a program that proved to be based on discrimination. Neither could answer although Martin made more at­ tempts than Beach. The black students finally gave up on Beach and continued to confront Martin. It must be understood here and now that the black students want answers to these demands. It is clear that Martin and Beach cannot supply them. When the blacks asked where Elkins was and demanded that he come out to the rally, Martin stood confused and Beach looked stupid. Our president must face reality on this campus. As one white student put it, •this campus is like a powder keg and about to go off." Issues such as these must be met head on. They ca#t be handled by a pacifier of the president. This just won’t work anymore. Black students have finally gotten wise to the tactics used by this univer­ sity. We are not going to sit by and n watch ourselves be made to look like i fools while the administration sits%ack and laughs at us. This event is not just a happening on campus. It is for real and these questions presented are going to be answered by someone who has authority. Our white brothers showed thl^ad­ ministration that this is not just a one way process. They threw just as many questions to the establishment as blacks did. Black and white students know change must come, but the old roots just sprout. Progress Is not checked at the student level. The administration is the one holding progress up. The old stlU have old ideas but the young have the new motor. BSU calls upon Nero Elkins to hear the cries of the students. He must no longer place the students in the arena. He must no longer let the students fight among themselves. We ask him to come before us not semester but now. The members of BSU are now using true black power. BSU president Bob McLeod says “the white student can support this cause." First he must open his mind to the fact that blacks are going to deal with black problems. The white support must come from white organizations. This is due to the fact that whites relate better to whites and can explain their positions on the racial situation much more clearly to their peers than can a black student. This is how black and white work together. I ask the white student not to get confused on this issue. All people are needed in a struggle such as this -- even Toms and white liberals.
